thread.title: Youngsters eager to get into rugby
thread.title_full: Youngsters eager to get into rugby - Telegraph

author: Oliver Pickup
title: Youngsters eager to get into rugby
text: Rugby union is a contact sport and injuries are an inevitable consequence. But record numbers of children are taking up the game, showing that for youngsters in particular the benefits far outweigh any physical risks. Will Greenwood, the 2003 World Cup winner and now Telegraph columnist, says that there is every reason to encourage children to play the oval-ball game. It fosters discipline, camaraderie and morals, and beefed-up athleticism doesn’t come into it at a young age. Figures released in July showed record numbers of children are playing the sport. World Rugby’s Get Into Rugby initiative drew 460,000 youngsters worldwide last year – a figure that is predicted to rise to 600,000 in 2015. “Life is about taking knocks, getting back off the floor and going again,” the former England centre says. “I am not immune to the worries of a parent – that my boy Archie might pick up an injury through rugby – but it is what a sport gives you, the feeling of being together as one and of building something. To me that is far more important.” Jonny Wilkinson, Greenwood’s match-winning team-mate in that Sydney final 12 years ago, has spoken of what rugby has given him. He says: “It is the values that you learn from playing in a team, and that when the team wins, everyone wins.” • For more information on health and lifestyle, visit vitality.com
